History
The origins of the WTO are in the GATT, which was created after World War II and was a successor organization to the Geneva-based Geneva Conference of 1947. The GATT was a treaty which provided an intellectual property right for the GATT member countries to make any rules for intellectual property rights as they see fit, without needing the consent of other GATT members. As GATT continued to operate, it was eventually replaced by the Uruguay Round, a GATT-based process which ended with the final agreements of Marrakech in 1994. In the 1990s, in addition to a series of bilateral trade agreements, a series of new rules and laws were added, as well as the establishment of a Multilateral Trading System that included the creation of a new trade organization called the WTO. Membership
The WTO currently comprises a total of 164 member countries. A number of these are former Soviet countries, with the majority of members being Western European countries.

the United Nations.passage: When the United Nations first began in 1945, it was largely unknown. A few world leaders met in London to sign the United Nations Charter. It was a vision of world peace. It was a vision, however, that required a great deal of sacrifice. That sacrifice was met by many. But for many others it went too far, and that is what you are likely to hear from many who fought in the UN. The world’s biggest power wanted in some ways, it seemed to them, to turn the UN into something like the Soviet Union. But that has not occurred, and the UN is one of the world’s major sources of international law and diplomacy. Of course, the UN still is an imperfect organization. It often is criticized for taking too much time to do things that many, many other world organizations have done before. It can be slow, but it is not at all like the Soviet Union. The UN has been a force in world politics for decades. Its biggest failure in the history of the planet occurred during the first 25 years. Today, the UN remains an important source of global power. But it has been 50 years since that first summit in London.

Henri Lauber.passage: "Henri Lauber (September 1, 1924 – October 11, 2010) was a Swiss mathematician. He is most famous for his research in the field of fluid mechanics. Lauber obtained a degree in engineering from the Ecole Polytechnique Fédérale de Lausanne (EPFL) in Switzerland in 1954, after which he undertook further studies in fluid dynamics at the California Institute of Technology. In 1957, he left Lausanne for the United States. Lauber worked at various places in California, including the Lawrence Livermore National Lab, University of California, Berkeley, and the National Aeronautics and Space Administration. He became well-known in the 1960s and 1970s as a professor of mathematics and fluid dynamics at UC Berkeley, but he left that position in 1978 to become a professor at the Swiss Federal Institute of Technology in Zurich. His main areas of research include boundary layer theory, internal fluid mixing in the wake of complex structures, and the effects of air density on fluid motion. Lauber's research has influenced the work of many modern fluid dynamicists and he is considered a pioneer of the subject."
